strTitle: Enjoy a Blue Cave & cute tropical fish snorkeling tour

strIntroduction: Take a glimpse of the world of Japanese Otaku culture on this 2.5-hour private tour of Tokyo’s famous Akihabara Electric Town. This intriguing area offers a paradise of stores and cafes catering to fans of video games, comic books, cosplay culture and discount electronics. Meet your guide at your hotel and move to Akihabara by public transport. This iconic area, which was nicknamed Akihabara Electric Town due to its origins as an electronics district after World War II, has evolved in recent years into a cultural hub for lovers of anime, manga, cosplay and video games, who refer to themselves as Otaku, or “nerds.” Begin your walking tour of Akihabara and enjoy an hour at this entertaining and shopping district. Finish your Akihabara excursion at Don Quijote, affectionately known by residents as “Donkey.” This sprawling retail superstore sells everything from luxury goods to everyday groceries. Literally every inch of shelf space is packed with products, offering a fun chance to dig for a bargain. Spend some time browsing this incredible store, then return to public transportation for the trip back to your hotel. Below is the schedule of the tour: -10:00 Meet at a hotel (or a station) -Akihabara: Kotobukiya, Don Quixote and toys, games, figure shops. Learn about Otaku culture from a private guide in this popular shopping district -Lunch time in Akihabara (lunch is not included in the tour, we help you find a restaurant according to your taste) -12:30 Disband
strTitle: Explore the Fantastic World of Otaku on an Akihabara tour!

strIntroduction: In this activity you will wear traditional Japanese wedding costumes, have photos of you taken in a wonderful garden and eat multi-dish Kaiseki meal for lunch in a well-known restaurant in Dazaifu, Fukuoka! Below are the details of the tour: Implementation: Weekdays only Tour type: Private tour Recommended to: Newlyweds and couples Tour schedule: 09:30: Rendezvous → Dazaifu Station → walk to "Shizen-an" restaurant 10:00: Start the make up & hair arrange by a professional staff 11:20: Wear kimono experence 12:00: Walk out to a beautiful garden and have photos taken. On rainy days you can have the photos taken in a Japanese-style room. 13:00: End of kimono experience 13:30: Enjoy a Kaiseki lunch (drinks not included) 14:30: Get photo data DVD from the camera staff & end the activity
strTitle: Wear traditional wedding costume & eat Kaiseki lunch,Dazaifu

strIntroduction: Pick up bicycles and head to Kofukuji Temple. This temple has a number of historic temples and a large pagoda. Ride bicycles to Todaiji Temple all the way weaving through deer meandering through beautiful parks. See the largest bronze statue of Buddha in its great hall. Make your way through the parks and ponds to the ancient Kasuga Taisha Shrine. Walk along the forests paths through 2000 stone lanterns. Bicycle along shady paths to photograph the scenic ponds and Ukimido Gazebo. After finishing the bicycle tour walk around the shopping arcades near Nara Station. There is a large variety of shops and restaurants. This is the end of the tour. I can show you back to the station or recommend a good place to grab a bite.
strTitle: Cycle through Temples, Shrines and Deer in Nara

strIntroduction: Japan is a difficult land for wine making, grapes suffer from hot and humid summers and frigid winters. But determined growers and winemakers have been perfecting their crafts, and local wine in Japan is experiencing a small renaissance. With our wine expert, we offer a day tour in the Katsunuma region, where 80 vineyards in Katsunuma produce 40% of the national production and is the most premier wine region of Japan. The day begins with a tour of one of the most important estate vineyard in Katsunuma and which produces particularly the authentic Japanese grape which raises some attention in the wine world, the “Koshu”. This visit can also be an opportunity to pick up and taste the grapes (only Sept./Oct.). Lunch is a good time around a rather special barbecue: The charcoal grill is made of volcanic rock from neighbor Mount Fuji, which has the reputation for tenderizing meat! The day continues with a visit of the Chateau Mercian, one of Japan’s oldest vineyard, founded in 1877. Their Chardonnais, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot has been shining, winning awards in wine tastings throughout Japan. On site visit to the factory and then the winery to learn all about wine making which ends with wine tasting of course!
strTitle: Go on a Katsunuma Wine Tour, home to Koshu wine

strIntroduction: The flea market opens on the morning of every Sunday in Tokushima city. Over 300 stalls are waiting for you. You can spend a good time just walking the large site filled with many stalls. There are various items of daily use, foods, drinks and more. There are also many antiques, so this flea market is recommended to people who have a keen interest in Japan. Enjoy the flea market in Tokushima!
strTitle: Visit and shop around a big-scale flea market in Tokushima

strIntroduction: First we’ll meet at our office in Harajuku before making our way to the farm by car. It takes about ninety minutes to get to the farm. Once on the farm, we will start picking seasonal blueberries. They are unbelievably juicy and sweet! After making our own smoothies and other creations to cool off under the summer sun, we will enjoy a lunch of Japanese-style chilled wheat noodles. During lunch our host will share with us how he got his start in farming. This farmer takes a deep spiritual approach to his work and teaches us about the god of farming that is believed to dwell in the woods near the blueberry farm. Enjoy this unusual access into the aesthetic and culture behind farming in Japan as well as this farmer's personal approach and story. Dates: Every Thursday Schedule: 1:00 PM Meet at our office in Harajuku and go to the farm together by car 2:30 PM-3:00 PM Pick blueberries 3:00 PM-4:00 PM Make smoothies 4:00 PM-5:30 PM Lunch with explanation of history and culture of the farm Things to bring: Beverage
strTitle: Learn the Ancient Way and Aesthetic of a Japanese Farm

strIntroduction: Most visitors to Tokyo will visit the most well-known sights – Asakusa, Shinjuku, Shibuya, Harajuku and the Meiji Shrine. These are all of course worth visiting, but Tokyo also offer a multitude of choices for travelers looking for a less touristy and typical Japanese experience. The real charm of Tokyo is more discreet. We can discover it in the maze of streets behind the main one, with a village atmosphere, miles away from urban life. It is warm and simple, full of nice shops with clean design as well as charming cafes and small bars. Our local experts can attest, straying off the beaten tourist path is the best way to get a once-in-a-lifetime experience in Tokyo. Most popular spots visited as follows: Imperial Palace / Tokyo Tower/ Asakusa/ Akihabara Electronics Town/ Meiji Shrine/ Shinjuku / Ginza / Aoyama-Shibuya-Harajuku fashion district/ Tsukiji Fish Market and so many other off the beaten track places.
strTitle: Discover Tokyo: The Harmony of Modernity and Tradition

strIntroduction: The village of Ogimi in northern Okinawa is renowned for having the highest life expectancy in Japan, a fact that locals attribute to their traditional cultivation of Shekwasa, a citric fruit related to the mandarin. Whether true fact or mere legend, the area is certainly one of the most beautiful locations in Japan with its warm climate and rich soil. The residents of the area promote organic farming methods by giving visitors the opportunity to engage in all aspects of fruit and vegetable planting and harvesting, but this short tour/experience is primarily about fruit picking. For this reason, participants should come prepared with: • comfortable footwear such as sneakers • long sleeves and trousers • gardening gloves You can also join a tour around Ogimi village where, among other things, you will see the traditional Bashoku cloth weaving that has been done in Okinawa for over 500 years.
strTitle: Enjoy Ogimi village fruits picking & village tour, Okinawa!

strIntroduction: This delightful private tour takes in some of the most picturesque sights that Hokkaido has to offer. Transportation is by a comfortable and convenient car relative to the size of your group, including English guides. Pick up is at Muroran Port at 09:00am, arriving at Lake Toya at 10:00am. This is a volcanic caldera lake and the northernmost lake in Japan that never ices. Marvel at the stunning natural beauty and the crystal clarity of the lake's water. From here, you will take the Mt. Usu ropeway to the observation platforms overlooking Shōwa-shinzan, a volcanic lava dome, and right next to the active volcano Mt. Usu. Here you will have plenty of time to enjoy the impressive scenery of Shikotsu-Toya National Park and have lunch (not included). At 02:00pm the tour will reach Jigokudani (Hell Valley) just above the town of Noboribetsu Onsen. As the main source of the town's famous hot spring waters, the volcanic activity in the valley includes hot steam vents and sulphurous streams; surely one of the most impressive sights in Japan! The tour will drop you off back at Muroran Port at 04:00 pm.
strTitle: Shore Excursion From Muroran to Lake Toya & Noboribetsu!

strIntroduction: The National Diet Building is the center of Japan’s politics as it is the place where Diet sessions are held. The building is in Nagata-cho, Chiyoda ward, Tokyo, and features a pyramid-like tower in its center. It was completed in 1936, after 17 years of work involving a total of 2.54 million people at a cost of 25,736,000 JPY. The central tower was the tallest building in Japan when it was completed. Entering the inside of the building is a special experience even for Japanese people. Consider this tour as one of your options during your stay in Japan. In the National Diet Building, you can see the lobby, conference hall, central hall with its gorgeous decorations and a rest lounge used by the Emperor. After exploring the National Diet Building, move to Kensei Kinenkan (memorial hall of the constitution process) located behind the Diet Building, and learn the history of Japan’s politics. And then walk to Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu, and enjoy the buffet-style lunch, including popular crab and roast beef! Schedule of the tour: 10:40: Meet at exit 1 of Kokkaigijido-mae subway station Visit the National Diet Building Visit the Kensei Kinenkan (free time to explore in about 20 minutes) 13:30: Move to Akasaka Excel Hotel Tokyu for lunch (about 90 minutes), end the tour at a convenient time (until 15:00) * The participants must be 4 years or older. However, infants 3 years or younger can join the tour for free (1 infant per adult). Be sure to let us know beforehand in this case About The National Diet of Japan voyag.in/2cDD4Ff Check the Tour Conditions link below. voyag.in/2c7AgMg
strTitle: Enjoy National Diet Tour and Buffet Lunch, Tokyo!

strIntroduction: Kagurazaka is a fashionable shopping and dining district along a sloping street in Tokyo. During the Edo Period, Kagurazaka was located just outside the outer moat of Edo Castle and gained prominence as an entertainment district with numerous geisha houses and restaurants. Some of the geisha houses survive in the district's narrow alleys to this date. While a geisha is female, a male geisha is called “taikomochi.” Currently, there are only 5 taikomochi in Japan. Why not enjoy taikomochi show in this historical place! Enjoy the genuine traditional Japanese cuisine and the Ozashiki (the party in a tatami room with a geisha) at the distinguished old restaurant, Kagurazaka Shimakin, which was established in 1869. We offer a special and reasonable taikomochi and unagi (eel) lunch course for you. This plan includes the guide, so it is one of the easiest and most affordable to see taikomochi performing in Tokyo. The following is the schedule: 12:00 Lunch 12:30 Performance 1 13:15 Break 13:30 Performance 2 14:00 Event end * If you are not a fan of unagi (eel), please let us know beforehand. It can be changed to tempura. * Note that you can take photos, but not videos. * Participants must be 6 years or older. Check the Tour Conditions link below. voyag.in/2c7AgMg
strTitle: Enjoy Japanese Taikomochi Show and Cuisine, Tokyo!

strIntroduction: The Sumida River Line runs from Asakusa to Hama Rikyu Onshi Teien (Hama Rikyu Gardens). In Asakusa, head to the river to board your boat for a relaxing 40-minute Sumida River cruise (with an English audio guide). You'll glide through Tokyo and go underneath 12 bridges, providing a different perspective on the city. Listen to recorded commentary about the sights you pass as you cruise along this historically significant waterway. The dock at Hama Rikyu is located within the garden's grounds. Hama Rikyu is a large, attractive landscape garden in central Tokyo. Located alongside Tokyo Bay, Hama Rikyu features seawater ponds which change levels with the tides. There is also a teahouse on an island where visitors can rest and enjoy the scenery. The traditional garden stands in stark contrast to the skyscrapers of the adjacent Shiodome district (※Please install "Tokyo Parks Navi"application corresponded to English). From Hama Rikyu, walk to Tsukiji Outer Market. The Tsukiji Outer Market, known as the Jogai Shijo, is Japan's "Food Town," where one can encounter all of Japan's traditional foods. A mixture of wholesale and retail shops along with numerous restaurants line the streets. This is where new culinary trends are born. Take a walk around and experience the taste of Japan first hand. We offer a special plan for you, which includes all the above. The following is the schedule: 10:20: Meeting up/Reception at Asakusa Pier of Tokyo Cruise 10:40: Sumida River Cruise from Asakusa to Hama Rikyu - Walk in Hama Rikyu - Walk from Hama Rikyu to Tsukiji Outer Market (15 – 20 minutes) - Free time in Tsukiji Outer Market 13:30: All-you-can-eat sushi 14:30: End of the tour * The course and time are subject to change. * You will walk for approximately 3 km. Wear comfortable shoes and clothes to walk in. * Participants must be 3 years or older. * Includes the cruise ticket, admission fee, guide, cruise map, Tsukiji map, and lunch. Check the Tour Conditions link below. voyag.in/2c7AgMg
strTitle: Enjoy River Cruise, Garden and Sushi in Tokyo!

strIntroduction: Fruit picking is one of the most popular activities in Japan for couples and families! A great place to enjoy this unique cultural experience is Nakagomi Orchard. Located in Yamanashi Prefecture, visitors can see the breathtaking beauty of Mt. Fuji in the middle of Mother Nature. There are a variety of fruit picking packages to choose from, so you can find your favorite combination. The availability depends on the season. A list of available fruit through the year is below: - Cherries - Peaches - Sweet nectarines - Plums - Nashi (Japanese pears) - Grapes - Prunes - Persimmons - Apples Directions to Nakagomi Orchard: - Head to JR Kofu Station in Yamanashi - Go to Platform Number 5 at JR Kofu Station's Bus Terminal - Get on a bus headed towards Nishino Keiyu (via Noshino) (30 minutes) - Get off at Sangai Bus Station - From the bus terminal, you will see a crossroads on the west side. - Go up the road about 500 meters and you will see a sign for the farm on your left. Note - Please contact the farm once you get off the bus at Sangai.
strTitle: Enjoy Fruit Picking at Nakagomi Orchard in Yamanashi!

strIntroduction: Have you ever heard of the Shamisen before? This guitar like instrument is played in accompaniment with a geisha's dancing, along with many other traditional settings. Why not take up this unique opportunity and learn to play this instrument? The beautiful and subtle tone represents the Japanese aesthetic and you will be able to experience it first hand. Lessons are taught by experts in Shamisen! To top it off, you can experience playing some Ozashiki games, normally played in very formal settings with Geishas. These simple yet historical games are unique and most of all, so much fun! You won't get to experience this outside of Japan, so hurry and book this before it sells out! Option detail: Duration- 1 hour Must be over 10 years old Note: Please understand that the local supplier for this activity is not fluent in English. Explanation will be given using basic English, a prepared signboard and gestures.
strTitle: Experience playing the Shamisen and play Ozashiki Games!

strIntroduction: Mt. Fuji is Japan's highest mountain and a nearly perfectly conically shaped volcano that has been worshiped as a sacred mountain for hundreds of years. It has also been popular among artists throughout the centuries. Lake Ashinoko was formed in the caldera of Mt. Hakone after the volcano's last eruption 3,000 years ago. Today, the lake with Mt. Fuji in the background is the symbol of Hakone and a wonderful sight. On this tour a helicopter will fly you up into the sky of Hakone Ashinoko, where Mt. Fuji is said to be viewed at its most beautiful. From the helicopter you will be able to enjoy the best views of Lake Ashinoko in combination with Mt. Fuji. Furthermore, you can look down on the beautiful spots from Tokyo to Mt. Fuji along the route. Surely there is no better way to enjoy the area and majestic Mt. Fuji than with this flight-tour. The following conditions will apply: * The cruising may be cancelled due to bad weather. In this case, you will receive the refund. * It is not guaranteed that Mt. Fuji is definitely seen. * The passenger must be 3 years or older. * According to the instructions of Civil Aviation Bureau, you must write down your body weight before boarding. Summary of the cruising: Available number of passengers: 2 – 5 Flight schedule: 9:30: Meeting up at Heliport 10:00: Departure 11:00 – 11:20: Coming back to Heliport Flight time: Airframe for 5 passengers: 60 minutes Airframe for 3 passengers: 80 minutes * Note that the airframe you board will be determined on the flight day. Check the Tour Conditions link below. voyag.in/2c7AgMg
strTitle: Enjoy the View of Mt. Fuji and Ashinoko from a Helicopter!

strIntroduction: Souvenir shopping can be a hassle when you have so many places to go with little time. But don't worry, on this page, you can simply select a product of your choice and it will be available to take home with you! The products are all local specialities of certain regions in Japan and they include traditional handcrafts, food, kitchen utensils and various others. Many are traditional products which are hard to access in general souvenir shops. Details are below. ** Product Line-up** --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 【Tsugaru painted Couple Soup Bowl in Kiri-box (with chopsticks)】ー13800JPY A speciality of the Aomori prefecture - a set of soup bowls in a Kiri(paulownia wood) box with two sets of matching chopsticks. By intentionally disregarding the last "polishing" step in Tsugaru painting, the bowls are presented with an intriguing design and stereoscopic effect. Often purchased as souvenirs or gifts in various occasions. - Size- Large chopsticks : length 23.5cm, handle width 0.8cm Middle-sized chopsticks : length 20.5cm, handle width 0.8cm Soup bowl: diametr 10.6cm, height 7cm Material: Natural Wood --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 【Tamamushi Lacquerware Wine Glass (Pair) 】ー9100JPY *Grand Prize of the Japanese Gift Competition 2015* A speciality of Sendai, Miyagi prefecture - a set of red and green wine glasses by Tamamushi lacquerware. Tamamushi lacquerware is a special style established in Sendai and is named as "Tamamushi (jewel beetle)" because the colors slightly change depending on the lighting, as do the wings on jewel beetles. The governor of the Miyagi prefecture presented this product to Caroline Kennedy, the US ambassador to Japan when she visited. Often purchased as souvenirs or gifts in various occasions, especially to overseas. Size: Length 5.9㎝ × Width 5.9㎝ × Height 14.8㎝ / each Material: Glass --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 【Nambu Iron Tetsubin (Cast Iron Kettle) 】ー17700JPY A speciality of Iwate Prefecture. Nambu Iron Tetsubins are made by pouring molten iron into clay or sand molds and was a utensil used in traditional Japanese Tea Ceremonies. By using the Tetsubin to boil water, the flavor significantly changes to become very mellow. This kettle can be used on IH cookers and the form was designed to represent a round moon. The patter is the traditional and unique Arale pattern. Size: Length 18.5cmｘWidth 22.5cm x Height 23cm Weight: 2.69kg Capacity: 1.8L Material: Cast Iron --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 【Hango Bento box 】ー 13380JPY A speciality of Akita prefecture. This Hango Bento Box is two-layered and made of Akita Japanese cedars, bent into this specific shape. It is a traditional craft designated by the national government. The design is featuring "Hango" a container used to cook rice and is very light and easy to hold. Size: 170 X 90 X 95 mm Capactity：Top Layer 390CC Bottom Layer 500CC (with partation) --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 【Kaji-sho Cold Forged Petit Knife】ー 14100JPY A speciality of Yamagata prefecture. This knife was created by "Kaji-sho" a project team of five smithing companies in Yamagata. The biggest feature of Japanese traditional blades is the Cold Forging technique. The smith cools the forged iron and shapes it again to strengthen the knife. Unique patterns only visible by this process appear and present a distinct originality. The handle is made of Sakura bark and is inner winding to implement a high usability without burden. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 【Kitakata Ramen】ー 3500JPY A speciality of Fukushima prefecture. This product includes 12 packets of Kitakata Ramen, one of the three famous local Ramens in Japan (others are Sapporo and Hakata). The biggest characteristic is its thick and wrinkled noodles, with a smooth soy sauce soup. This would be a perfect gift for anyone who would like to taste the true Japanese Ramen! --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- * We cannot deliver overseas, the delivery option is only for hotels in Japan. * Please be sure to consume all foodstuffs as soon as possible. * Once submitted, orders may not be cancelled. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ※ Important Product Delivery & Pickup Information - Please Read Carefully ※ 1. Product Delivery We will deliver your product to your hotel in advance for your concierge to hold for you. The product will be available upon check-in. If you would like us to deliver the products to your hotel, please provide us with the following information: - Hotel name - The full name used for your reservation - Check-in date Please note: - We require at least 3 full business days for delivery. If placing a last minute order within 3 days of your visit, or if you do not provide us your hotel information at least 3 full business days prior, you'll need to collect your products from our Tokyo office in Shibuya. - If your hotel reservation details change, please tell us immediately through the Voyagin dashboard. - We only deliver to hotels with a concierge with whom we can confirm the receipt of the product delivery. We do not deliver products to hostels, guesthouses, or private residences. Please let us know if you are not staying at a hotel so we can provide our office details for you to pickup the products. 2. Product Pickup: If you are not staying at a hotel, book within 3 days of your stay, or prefer to pickup your products, you can collect them from our Tokyo office in Shibuya. strTitle: Buy Japanese local specialities as souvenirs!

strIntroduction: When travelling to a new destination, there’s nothing better than trying local culinary specialties to get to know a place! On this 3-hour tour, i will show you my favorite spots to eat and drink while experiencing a feel of the old Japan. Let's meet at Ginza Station, a line convenient with different metro lines. We will slowly walk to our first destination where you will discover a thriving restaurant district built alongside the train tracks! This district has plenty of small drinking spots and colorful restaurants that have been open since the 1950s. Typically tiny, these restaurants expand into the street during the warm season, creating a unique and lively atmosphere. It is in this area, commonly known as Yakitori alley, that we will begin our culinary expedition! After a few delicious yakitori (grilled meat on skewers), we’ll diversify our excursion with other classic izakaya food, like grilled fish with miso and even an okonomiyaki! Mmmmmm, delicious! In total, we will visit 4 restaurants, each with a different vibe and adding to the experience! All our tours can be held in English and in French.
strTitle: Enjoy authentic izakaya food and yakitori in Tokyo!

strIntroduction: We will begin by taking a quick 20 minutes time to discuss the itinerary and concepts that will help optimize your photography and let you make the most of where you are. To do this, your guide will introduce you to basic and more advanced topics of photography such as some often overlooked basics of composition and exposure. Let us then depart and attempt to put these notions into practice, visiting new concepts as we go along! We will spend an hour exploring Asakusa Station and the surrounding area including the Sensoji Temple. Then, we will walk and continue on our way to Ueno Station and spend the rest of our time visiting the trackside market place: a place so diverse and teeming with life it will leave no shortage of photographic opportunities! We will arrive in this rich neighbourhood just in time for the end of the work day, when Tokyo salary men go out to relax after a day’s work. The shops are open late so we’ll be sure to capture the area’s undeniably charming atmosphere! Our tour photographer’s role will be to guide you through this local labyrinth so that you don't miss a beat! This is an absolutely thrilling and fun tour that will surely satisfy the shutterbug in you!
strTitle: Discover Tokyo on a Classic Photo Tour

strIntroduction: ■ Limitation on number of people Minimum of 2 persons with a maximum of 5 persons ※The application will be closed when the number of participants reaches the limit. ■ Location Art Gallery Fukushima (10 min walk from JR Kawaguchi Station) ■ Materials We will provide text, Japanese writing paper, brush, ink and other utensils for calligraphy writing. ■ Lecturer introduction Mrs. Genpo Fukushima is a Japanese calligrapher who participates in calligraphy field actively not only in Japan but in many other countries. She has won numerous awards through those exhibitions. Not only does she hold calligraphy seminars in Japan, she has also been invited to lecture in foreign universities such as the University of Amsterdam. In the recent years, she has conducted demonstrations and calligraphy workshops in “New Zealand Japan Day” and other Japanese cultural events in other foreign countries.
strTitle: Take part in a Japanese Calligraphy Workshop

strIntroduction: You can start this tour at 15:00. The schedule is below: 15:00 Pick you up in Yokohama Station If you want to get picked up in your hotel, please ask me in a message. 16:00 Rent a small electric car at Nissan Global Gallery. Ride around Yokohama. You can explore Minatomirai 21 area, Nissan Global Gallery, Landmark Tower and more! Notes about the car: - I will drive it. You don't need to worry about driving licence. - We can take 1 person at a time if you are a big group 17:00 Go to Minatomirai area in Yokohama Night cruising Yokohama Bay (1 hour) 19:00 Go to Yakitori Bar in Yokohama, Tsuruyacho The Yakitori bar's name is "Yokohama-shouten". Drink beer, Japanese sake, and eat yakitori, a Japanese style BBQ. If you can't eat chicken, please tell me that in advance. 21:00 Go back to Yokohama Station
strTitle: Explore Yokohama and have a Yakitori dinner

strIntroduction: Kappabashi Street is the place all the restaurant business people go to purchase knives, display goods, dishes, stove, and refrigeratosr for their professional use. Food sample is an important tool for restaurants in Japan since those displays can attract a lot of customers and they must be displayed in front of the restaurant. You will visit Kappabashi Street and buy those professional tools or make your own foods samples there for your home use. Your experience here will be totally awesome and this food sample is one of best souvenir from your visit to Japan. Enjoy your stay in Kappabashi Street! The schedule of the tour is below: 9:00 Meet at your hotel 10:00 Visit Kappabashi Street 11:00 Food sample school 13:00 Go back to your hotel
strTitle: Visit Kappabashi street and make food samples with a guide

strIntroduction: Yokohama is a port city and it was the entrance of Japan 150 years ago. Yokohama was one of first cities to accept international culture after Japan opened the doors to the world 150 years ago. Visitors from other countries developed their own culture in Yokohama and we can feel it while walking around. 3.7 million people live in Yokohama, making it No.2 populated city in Japan and it is a real international city. We will visit the bay area and enjoy a totally different atmosphere from other Japanese cities. While we walk Yokohama bay area, we will visit the Cup Noodle museum and make our own cup Ramen noodle there. You can keep your cup noodle as a souvenir. After that, we will walk to the biggest China town in Japan and taste Chinese Ramen noodle. As you know, Chinese Ramen noodles is the origin of Japanese Ramen noodles. You will enjoy walking around the Yokohama bay area and see the harbor view park, Motomachi shopping area, Yamashita Park and so on. We will move to Shin-Yokohama and visit the Ramen museum. You will find 9 famous Ramen shops from all over Japan. You may enjoy your favorite Ramen noodle in a 1950s atmosphere. Below is the itinerary of the tour: 10:00 Meet at JR Sakuragi-cho Sta. 10:30 Cup Noodle Museum 12:00 China town 12:30 Walk in Yokohama Bay area 15:00 Yokohama Ramen Museum 16:00 End this tour at JR Shin-Yokohama Sta.
strTitle: Enjoy 3 kinds of ramen noodles in Yokohama

strIntroduction: 3 Day Horse Riding Course in Iida city, Nagano prefecture: enjoy the undisturbed, beautiful nature of Japan Following a pick-up at Chubu International Airport or Nagoya train station in the afternoon, we will get on a highway bus to go to Nagano, home to the Winter Olympics of 1998. After about 2.5 hrs (during the time you will also be able to enjoy the beautiful country side scenery of Japan), we will arrive at the stable where we will be based for the next 3 nights. We will have our first group dinner at the stable's Italian restaurant with one of the most magnificent view of the Japan Alps. You can enjoy a relaxing evening. Day 1 & 2 The next morning after breakfast, you will go to the stable to prepare your horse and start your riding lessons! (You can also learn stable management as an option.) Then after lunch you have an option of either another riding lesson or a tour around the city such as: hot spring town, rafting, mountain hikes, fruit picking, etc. Meals: you will not only be able to enjoy the local specialty of Nagano (soba noodles, bbq, etc.) but also amazing Italian cuisine of a master Japanese chef. Day 3 You will have a morning riding lesson and at noon, head back to Nagoya or we can help you to arrange transport to other locations. Nagoya will be a perfect place to get back to city life to enjoy shopping, food and also local temples.
strTitle: Horse riding lesson & trekking in the Japan Alps

strIntroduction: On this hands-on tour you’ll learn to put a Japanese spin on this globally popular craft, mangekyo (literally, ten thousand glorious mirrors.) With unique beads that are reminiscent of Japanese sweets and traditional Japanese paper, you’ll use a variety of accessories and pieces collected by our host to create beautiful kaleidoscopes. You’ll also get a crash course in how our host got their start, and the history of how this once only European craft made its way over and flourished in Japan. Dates: October 18th and 25th Schedule: 12:45 Meet at Okachimachi Station (Yamanote line and Keihin-Tohoku lines) 13:00 - 13:30 Host explains kaleidoscope making and mechanics 13:30 - 14:30 Hands-on crafting time! 14:30 - 15:00 Picture opportunity + Q&A Duration: 13:00-15:00
strTitle: Experience making Japanese Kaleidoscope!

strIntroduction: Ohhhh Tokyo, with your big corporate headquarters and massive mobs of people doing very important things. And then Kyoto, with your high culture, fancy temples, gardens, and refinement. Yay. But this is OSAKA, and -- how to put it nicely? -- we don't care about your charmed lives. We care about eating. Do you care about eating? We thought so. But where is that food coming from? Join us as we walk around not one, not two, not three, but four (!) varied marketplaces sure to indelibly delight. We'll also of course explore and talk about the neighborhoods around these historic marketplaces. Your native English (and fluent Japanese) speaker is eager to tell you all about the various markets you will see. Starting time is 1:00 pm. Stop one is in Namba, for the highfalutin decadence of the department store marketplace. Superlatives shall flow as you gawk at delicious prepared foods, high end fish, meats, and vegetables. Then there's the festive and diverse scene of Kuromon Ichiba, where street vendors jostle with retailers, all offering up some darn scrumptious vittles. Lots of quirk around here too. After our Namba dalliances, we'll hop on the subway for a quick ride to Tsuruhashi, known as the Koreatown of Osaka. Narrow streets teem with all things Korean, be they raw, cooked, pickled, fried, simmered, or otherwise primed for your consideration. There's also an area to shop around for clothing that is, well, quintessentially Osaka. On to the JR Loop Line we then go for about a 10 minute ride to Tenma, another great marketplace that is lighter on the Korean and heavier on the vegetables, but with lots of other stuff to see as well. This is possibly the most modern and local (in the "everyday shopping" sense) of all four marketplaces. We'll wrap up the tour in Tenma, from where you will either be directed to the subway or JR line (whichever works best for you) to get back to your hotel, OR you can take the "Enjoy an adventurous evening of food and drink in Osaka" tour (you may add this option at time of purchase of this marketplace tour). The Food and Drink tour takes you to three stand-up bars for food and drink in two different neighborhoods. More can be read about this option by referring to the tour's independent listing here on Voyagin: https://www.govoyagin.com/activities/japan-osaka-enjoy-an-adventurous-evening-of-food-and-drink-in-osaka/4076 It's going to be a great afternoon of looking, learning, and maybe a bit of grazing too, so don't delay, book today :)
strTitle: See the markets of Osaka, from High Style to Highly Local

strIntroduction: This is one day luxury tour in Tokyo. There are many many places you should visit in Tokyo and in this day trip you can see the best of the city. You can visit some of the city’s top shrines and luxury shopping areas before taking a cruise on Tokyo Bay. We pick you up at your staying hotel in the morning and take you to the shrines first. Depending on the number of participants, it might be a group tour; it might be a private/family tour. If you prefer a private one, you may need to pay an additional cost. First, we take you to the Meiji Shrine or Meiji Jingu. Meiji Jingu is a Shinto shrine. Shinto is called Japan's ancient original religion, and it is deeply rooted in the way of Japanese life and the shrine was dedicated to the Imperial Family in 1926. Walk along the gardens that surround the shrine as you listen to more details about its importance from guide staff. Head back to your bus, driving past the Japanese House of Parliament as you continue on to the Imperial Palace East Garden. The current Imperial Palace is located on the former site of Edo Castle, a large park area surrounded by moats and massive stone walls in the center of Tokyo, a short walk from Tokyo Station. It is the residence of Japan's Imperial Family. This is the “home” to a traditional Japanese garden, tea pavilion, stone walls and a moat, is situated within the complex of an Edo period castle. When you get hungry, we'll take you to the Nakamise Shopping Street. In fact, Nakamise is one of the oldest shopping centers in Japan and has a brightly-colored thoroughfare of food vendors and souvenir shops that leads to Asakusa Temple, one of Japan’s most important Buddhist sites. Asakusa can easily be explored on foot. Leave Asakusa Temple, heading by bus for the Ginza district, a conglomerate of shopping stores. From there, enjoy lunch overlooking Hamarikyu Garden, a seaside garden from the Edo period. If you like to enjoy premium and high-class dining around Asakusa, there are several restaurants as follows: 1. Imahan Bekkan. Actually they have special course for foreigners such as 8,000 JPY and a 10,000 JPY course including Omi beef sukiyaki, tempura, shabu-shabu and dessert. Also they can serve vegetarian course as well. 2. Kinsen. This is a tempura restaurant serving from 7000 JPY courses. When you are done with your lunch, you'll take a ride through the Tokyo Bay. From the boat’s vantage point, you’ll have excellent views of the Tokyo skyline, along with Rainbow Bridge. Finish your cruise and spend some time checking out the shopping at the waterfront Aqua City Odaiba complex. You’re likely to see Tokyo Big Sight and TC Building while you enjoy shopping. At the end of your tour at Tokyo station, go back to your hotel.
strTitle: 40% OFF Take a one day Luxury Tour around Tokyo

strIntroduction: Imagine, you meet locals and get some information that is NOT listed in guidebooks, nor even in social networks. Do you know the word "Salaryman"? It is a generic name for normal office workers. They often go for a drink with their bosses and colleagues after work in a practice called Nominication. Now you can experience this culture. Join us! First of all, I will pick you up at your accommodation or Shizuoka Station, or we will meet up somewhere you like. Then we will go around a local town. Even if it is touristy area, I will show you places that tourists don't know and just pass. After that we will go to an Izakaya alley and enjoy foods and drinks: Yakitori, Seafood BBQ, Okonomiyaki (thin and flat pancake cooked on a hot plate with bits of meat, seafood and chopped cabbages) etc. The price is per person and includes foods and drinks, but doesn't include transportation. If you have any requests or questions, please don't hesitate to ask. I am looking forward to meeting you. Below is the itinerary of this experience: 5:00 pm or 8:00 pm: - Depart from JR Shizuoka Station Please feel free to contact me.
strTitle: Enjoy cuisine and bar culture in a local bar in Shizuoka

strIntroduction: This is a trip to Izu, Shizuoka. Itinerary 9:00 a.m. -Depart from Mishima Station of JR Line If you cannot come to Mishima by Shinkansen, I'll come to pick you up at Tokyo Station by Shinkansen. Please feel free to contact me. -Shuzenji (Shuzenji Temple)〔60 min〕 To pray at Shuzenji-temple To take a look at the town and its historical places and to go to the street filled with bamboos. To take pictures behind this bamboo forest. -Omuro-yama (Mt Omuron) 〔50 min〕 To take the lift to look at a panoramic scene from the top of the mountain and to take a walk around the top. To take pictures of Mt. Fuji and you together if it’s fine. -Lunch〔60 min〕 At the fish-market in Ito city. You can have home-made fresh fish at the bar - Jogasaki Coast〔30 min〕 You can see a splendid scene from a thrilling bridge. And you can have a wonderful experience trekking from cape to cape. You can take pictures of the splendid scenery. -Kuroiwa Onsen (Kuroiwa hot springs) 〔30 min〕 You can experience a hot spring just next to the sea level. You can take a Japanese-style bath (called Onsen) and see a beautiful view. This Onsen will make your skin smooth. If you have any requests or questions, please don't hesitate to ask. I am looking forward to meeting you. -Return to Mishima Station Return from Mishima to Tokyo for one hour by Shinkansen. This course will take about 6 hours to get around. If you apply for add-on options, it will take more.
strTitle: Eat fresh fish caught in Suruga Bay, Izu, Shizuoka

strIntroduction: The rise of Japanese whisky can be traced to 2001 when Nikka’s Yoichi whisky was named the “Best of the Best” in an international tasting by Whisky Magazine. In 2003, Suntory’s 30-year-old Hibiki clinched the top award at the International Spirits Challenge - and continued to win awards at this prestigious competition every year for the next 11 years. Japanese whisky is crafted in Scottish style - explaining its spelling as “whisky” and not “whiskey” as is done in Irish and American varieties - as the pioneers of Japanese whisky had learnt the production process from Scotland. Nikka Whisky, founded by the Scottish distillery-trained Masataka Taketsuru, and Suntory are the oldest whisky makers in Japan. Both of their founders strove to create the perfect dram that suited the Japanese palate. Japanese whisky is said to be delicate, smooth and floral, with a range of peatiness. Get a guided tour of around 60 minutes, which includes whisky tasting. English pamphlets are available. The premises are not open for viewing otherwise. Buy limited edition whiskies at the retail shop here. The location is near Sendai city, Miyagi prefecture.
strTitle: Nikka Miyagikyo Whisky Distillery Tour & Tasting

strIntroduction: Founded in 1934 by Masataka Taketsuru who went to Scotland in 1918 to study the art of whiskey making, this location was chosen for meeting the requirements of a cold climate, high quality water source, abundant supply of peat and being near a forest where wood can be obtained to make barrels and coal. Yoichi Single Malts won the “Best of the Best” 2001 competition by Whisky Magazine. Yoichi, to the north-west of Sapporo on the island of Hokkaido, still carries out traditional distillation, using coal to direct fire the stills, something which is no longer seen even in Scotland these days. The earth floors of the cask warehouses are designed to maintain a year-round humidity appropriate for whisky maturation. The distillery can make various styles of whiskies, ranging from Lowland through to Islay, and these can be sampled for free at the bar. Get your secured reservation for the 60-min guided tour today before places are snapped up! English pamphlets and audio guides are available.
strTitle: Nikka Yoichi Whisky Distillery Tour & Tasting

strIntroduction: This is a traditional Japanese dance lesson. You can take the private lesson, or you can take the group lesson (up to 5 persons). No dance skills are required. I can teach the dance to children from 2 years old, and also to adults. My lesson studio is near to the Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo (about 3 min walk from the hotel). The hotel has a very beautiful Japanese garden. You can enjoy walking around the garden before or after the lesson. The flow of the lesson is as follows: 1) We will meet at the lobby of the Hotel Chinzanso Tokyo, and walk to the lesson studio (about 3 min walk). 2) You can choose your Kimono from my collections, including Yukata (the casual style of Kimono), stage costumes and so on. (Some Kimono may need additional charge) 3) Wear the Kimono. 4) Let's dance "Nihon Buyo"! (about 30 min) 5) You'll change into your clothes. 6) I'll give you a Japanese fan as your souvenir. 7) End of the experience
strTitle: Experience Japanese traditional dance & wearing kimono

strIntroduction: Itsukushima Shrine (Japanese: 厳島神社 Itsukushima-jinja) is a Shinto shrine on the island of Itsukushima (popularly known as Miyajima), best known for its "floating" torii gate. It is located in the city of Hatsukaichi in Hiroshima Prefecture, Japan. Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park (広島平和記念公園 Hiroshima Heiwa Kinen Kōen) is a memorial park in the center of Hiroshima City. Its dedicated to the legacy of Hiroshima as the first city in the world to suffer a nuclear attack, and to the memories of the bomb's direct and indirect victims (of whom there may have been as many as 140,000). We will use public transportation, tram, JR line, ferry, etc. I can arrange this tour according to your request. Example schedule of the tour: 9:00 meet at your hotel or JR train station. 10:00 Peace Memorial Park (museum, A-bomb dome and so on) 12:00 Lunch by your request (Okonomiyaki is a local specialty) 13:00 Miyajima (Itsukushima Shrine, Daishoin temple and so on) 15:30 Leave the island 16:45 Send you off wherever you want in Hiroshima.
strTitle: See the A-bomb Dome in Hiroshima and Miyajima

strIntroduction: Starting time is flexible between 3 pm and 7 pm, and the tour lasts for 2 hours. *Starting time is flexible and can be arranged upon your request; however, there may be waiting time to secure seats later in the evening, as most local bars do not take reservations. Who are the bar hopping masters? - Fluent in English even after drinking a considerable amount of alcohol! - Have a deep knowledge of the local area including Tokyo's very complicated transportation system. Enjoy the nightlife at Tokyo's local bars! Minimum age is 20 years! Please advise about any specific dietary requirements or food allergies at time of booking. Inclusions: Tour escort/host Exclusions: Food and drinks Transportation to/from bars Departure time: Between 3 pm and 7 pm
strTitle: 30% OFF Backstreet bar tour of Tokyo with a local tour guide

strIntroduction: Here is a list of places that I will take you to in Tokyo: - Asakusa. You can walk and eat at Nakamise street which looks like old Edo Tokyo. If you want you can pull a good luck charm called Omikuji at Sensoji Temple. This is the best spot if you like the image of old Japan. - Ueno Park. It's a cultural mecca with a number of museums including the prestigious Tokyo National Museum and the delightful Shitamachi Museum with its display of old Tokyo, Ueno Zoo and many galleries. We will go to Lake Shinobazu and around park. - Izakaya "WATAMI" (bring cash with you). This is a Japanese bar type called Izakaya. You can spend a great night here. We promise you reasonable prices. Izakaya is a Japanese-style pub popular among working people, which offers a variety of foods.
strTitle: 30% OFF Tour all major places in Asakusa area, Tokyo
